Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Incorporating Physiological Variation in Mechanistic Range Models for Ecological Forecasting
Award.AbstractNarration:
These scientists will use computer models to investigate the impacts of climate change on the continental distribution of a well studied and widespread lizard. The model will link the attributes of individual lizards to assess how whole populations of lizards adapt to specific environmental conditions. For example, the model considers how temperature and rainfall limit lizard activity, such as feeding. Feeding activity is then related to survival and reproduction. By monitoring the behavior and measuring internal activity of lizards across the entire United States, the investigators will be able to compare how variation in these attributes leads to different predictions about how climate in different regions should affect lizards. Then the PIs will evaluate how the evolution of physiology would affect the distribution of lizards under various climate change scenarios. This project will set the stage for a new modeling approach that considers how evolutionary adaptation and gene flow can help determine the geographic range of a species.

Predicting the ranges of species and how they will shift during conditions of environmental change is a major challenge for biologists that has important applications to conservation. Existing models either fail to incorporate important processes or are too abstract to apply to real populations. This project will expand our knowledge by incorporating ecological processes into a model that is tailored to a real species of lizards. This model could then be generalized and applied to other species in the future. The project will make significant contributions to the missions of research and education at three universities in Arizona, North Carolina and Texas. It will train students from under-represented groups, will develop cross-university workshops on these new models and approaches, and should lead to software usable by resource managers to forecast biological responses to environmental change. The project participants will provide public lectures, prepare non-technical publications, and develop web pages with summaries and activities designed for the public, in addition to writing the usual scientific papers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced our understanding of climate change and its potential impacts on animals. Previous models suggested that warming would hurt tropical species but potentially benefit temperate ones. However, these models focused on adult animals, ignored early life stages that lack the ability to regulate their body temperature. The PIs built a model that covers an entire life cycle and used this model to investigate the impact of climate on North American lizards. The model describes how each stage (embryo, juvenile, and adult) experiences and responds to climate. Simulations started with the development of embryos in soil and then calculated how temperature limits the growth of juveniles and the reproduction of adults. These performances were integrated to calculate the rate of population growth. By mapping locations where population can grow the researchers were able to define the potential range of a species. 

To use the model, the PIs measured the behavior and physiology of lizards throughout the United States. They also conducted novel experiments to quantify how embryos respond to warming that occurs in soils. Unlike previous studies, which used artificial exposures to constant temperatures, the PIs experiments included brief yet potentially important exposures to high temperatures. Indeed, brief exposure to a threshold temperature killed all embryos, but temperatures just below this threshold promoted rapid growth and development to hatching. Therefore, the PIs had to know the temperatures experienced by embryos at each hour of the day to predict their survival.

To characterize the thermal environments of embryos in the past and predict them for the future, the PIs used data from climatologists to calculate microclimates at a very fin scale. The produced a dataset describing temperatures, humidities, wind speeds, and vegetation on an hourly basis for past and future years (1980-2000 and 2080-2099). These data enabled the PIs to learn that temperate lizards might suffer as climates warm, primarily because embryos will reach their lethal temperature more often. Thus, including the embryonic stage and considering highly-resolved microclimate qualitatively altered predictions about the fate of lizards during climate change. The project also revealed a better understanding of how climate affects adult animals, because highly-resolved climates had never been available before. The climate data generated by this project are available to researchers and the public who wish to use the data for other purposes.

Predicting the ranges of species and how these ranges will shift during environmental change is a timely challenge for biologists with important applications for conservation. Previous models either failed to incorporate key ecological processes or were too abstract to apply to real populations. This project improved our understanding of species ranges by incorporating ecological processes into a model that is tailored to a real species. This model could be generalized and applied to other species.

This research led not only to publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals but also to broader impacts. The PIs trained future scientists at Arizona State University, the University of North Carolina, and the University of Texas, including members of underrepresented groups at both undergraduate and graduate levels. In particular, the research conducted during this project is featured in an 8-week module for introductory biology students, titled “Why should I care about climate change?” This module, which cover biological concepts spanning the scales of genes to the biosphere, raises students’ awareness of environmental problems created by human population growth. The PIs have also disseminated the work through podcasts and websites designed to educate people raging from K-12 students to adults.
